fields.name: Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation
fields.description: Difficulty: Hard-- Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation is the family of diseases encompassing NGLY1 deficiency.  These docs will provide an overview of the general space of related genetic disorders, and treatments identified to these closely related disorders may be relevant to NGLY1 patients. There are over 400 docs in this set, please help mark them up.

fields.name: Practice
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium/Hard-- Practice the skills you learned by marking this set of docs which contain abstracts on diseases affecting some of your fellow Mark2Curators? lives.  You will always be paired with a good answer in this set so you can improve your understanding of the rules and concepts.

fields.name: Alacrima
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium-- Alacrima is an abnormality in the production of tears.  Children with NGLY1 have a lot of symptoms which are seen in many other disorders, but Alacrima is a symptom unique to just a few diseases like NGLY1 deficiency or Triple A syndrome. Are there treatments in other diseases with this symptom that may be applicable to NGLY1 patients?  Mark these docs and help researcher find out.

fields.name: O-linked Glycosylation Disorders
fields.description: Difficulty: Fiendish!-- Can researchers gain insight on the genes involved in N-linked glycosylated protein degradation and compensatory mechanisms by studying O-linked glycosylation disorders? Are there treatment strategies for O-linked glycosylation disorders that might apply to NGLY1 deficiency?  Let?s find out--mark these docs.

fields.name: FBX2 or ENGASE
fields.description: Difficulty: Hard-- F-box protein 2 (FBX2) and endo-beta-N-acetylglucosaminidase (ENGASE) are two genes which were identified to be potentially relevant to NGLY1 deficiency.  There are very few papers linked to these two genes; but they may hold valuable clues regarding other relevant topics to search.  Help us find out by Marking the docs in this set!

fields.name: Oxidative Stress
fields.description: Difficulty: Fiendish-- Oxidative stress can cause proteins to misfold and accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).  This can trigger the ER stress response (including the Unfolded Protein Response) a cellular stress response crucial for protein homeostasis.  Issues with overactivation of the unfolded protein response (UPR) have been associated with a number of neurodegenerative diseases. N-glycanase 1 is important for cleaving sugar molecules off of proteins allowing them to be degraded.  NGLY1 deficiency would be expected to cause N-glycosylated protein accumulation. Can we learn more about the issues caused by protein accumulation and ultimately the symptoms of NGLY1 by investigating Oxidative stress and UPR? Help us find out!

fields.name: misfolded AND mitochondrial 1
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium/Hard-- Misfolded proteins can aggregate and trigger the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response which affects normal cellular processes like autophagy and mitochondrial function.  Mitochondria play a key role in producing energy for the cell and mitochondrial dysfunction is linked with many different diseases such as Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy,  Friedreich's ataxia, Wilson's disease, hereditary spastic paraplegia, and more. Deficiency in N-glycanase 1 is expected to result in the aggregation of N-glycosylated proteins. Does the literature surrounding protein misfolding and mitochondrial function hold clues about the mechanism of disease progression in NGLY1 deficiency? Mark the docs to help us find out!

fields.name: Eeyarestatin
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium/Hard-- Eeyarestatin is a small molecule inhibitor of VCP.  VCP or Valosin Containing Protein is an important mediator of protein homeostasis and plays an important role in endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, autophagy, proteasome function, and more. Can Eeyarestatin improve our understanding of the pathological mechanisms behind NGLY1-deficiency? Mark this small doc set now!

fields.name: misfolded AND mitochondrial 2
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium/Hard-- Mitochondria play a key role in producing energy for the cell and mitochondrial dysfunction is linked with many different diseases such as Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, Friedreich's ataxia, Wilson's disease, hereditary spastic paraplegia, and more. Deficiency in N-glycanase 1 is expected to result in the aggregation of N-glycosylated proteins.  Protein aggregation is an expected trigger of the ER stress response which can affect mitochondrial function. Does the literature surrounding protein misfolding and mitochondrial function hold clues about the mechanism of disease progression in NGLY1 deficiency? Mark the docs to help us find out!

fields.name: Autophagy and Seizures
fields.description: Difficulty: Medium/Hard-- Autophagy is a crucial biological process that allows cells to degrade and recycle cellular components.  It is required for proper cell homeostasis, and alterations in autophagy have been linked to arthritis, cancer, infectious disease, and more.  NGLY1-deficiency is expected to cause aggregation of glycoproteins.  How might autophagy be perturbed in NGLY1-deficiency?  Are there links between autophagy perturbations and symptoms of NGLY1-deficiency?  Are there modulators of autophagy which could potentially be used as therapeutics for NGLY1-deficiency?  Help us find out by marking the docs in this quest.

fields.name: Myelin and Autophagy
fields.description: Myelin is an outgrowth of a type of glial cell that is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system. Demyelination, or the loss of myelin sheaths is observed in many diseases such as Multiple Sclerosis, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, and more. Autophagy is a crucial biological process that allows cells to degrade and recycle cellular components including myelin. How might autophagy be perturbed in NGLY1-deficiency? Are there links between autophagy perturbations and symptoms of NGLY1-deficiency? Are there modulators of autophagy which could potentially be used as therapeutics for NGLY1-deficiency? Help us find out by marking the docs in this quest.

fields.name: Myelin, Autophagy, and Seizures
fields.description: Autophagy is a crucial biological process that allows cells to degrade and recycle cellular components including myelin--an outgrowth of a type of glial cell that is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system. Demyelination, or the loss of myelin sheaths is observed in many diseases such as Multiple Sclerosis, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, and more.  Seizures and other movement disorders may also relate to perturbations in myelination. How might autophagy be perturbed in NGLY1-deficiency? Are there links between autophagy perturbations and symptoms of NGLY1-deficiency? Are there modulators of autophagy which could potentially be used as therapeutics for NGLY1-deficiency? Help us find out by marking the docs in this quest.
